title: Now hiring frontend web designer HTML/CSS

author.name: Damian Taggart
author.description: Over the past decade Damian has grown Mindshare Studios from a very small (spare bedroom) operation into one of the more established and sought after web design and app development firms in the Southwest. Mindshare Studios won Small Business of the Year in 2014 from the Santa Fe Chamber of Commerce. Before founding Mindshare Studios, Damian worked as a web and multimedia developer for St. John’s College and Central New Mexico Community College, respectively. Damian has also worked doing freelance web design and internet/technology consulting. He is an avid open source technology enthusiast. Damian serves the City of Santa Fe on both the Economic Development Review Committee and the Business and Quality of Life Committee. Additionally, Damian is a co-owner of the experimental arts collective Meow Wolf which has partnered with George RR Martin to open a 20,000 square foot art experience in Santa Fe. Damian graduated cum laude with an interdisciplinary degree in Media Arts and English from the University of New Mexico in 2003. Damian lives in Santa Fe with his wife Lara and two sons, Jack and Henry.

content:
We are currently looking for someone to join our team with solid HTML and CSS skills. The job will entail coding web and app layouts using standard frameworks like Bootstrap and Semantic UI as well as supporting Mindshare clients, troubleshooting, and debugging websites. This is a frontend development position so programming with JS or PHP is a plus, but not required.

Learn more or apply now »

title: (lisp-like (template-helpers (for meteor.js)))

author.name: Winston Riley
author.description:
Winston Riley graduated cum laude with a degree in Philosophy before turning to study Computer Science at the University Of New Mexico. Winston leads the Mindshare programming team.

Outside of writing code at Mindshare Studios, he is fascinated with functional programming, programming language design, and loves the Lisp family of languages.

Winston has lived in New York City, Kyoto Japan, and was raised in Santa Fe.

He is a long time practicing photographer and design enthusiast. 

He lives and works in the beautiful desert of Santa Fe, New Mexico.

content:
I just released a Meteor package (a pet project of sorts) on atmospherejs.com.

With the release of Meteor 1.2 Spacebars now supports functional composition. Using a prefix notation  (reminiscent of LISP) you can compose function calls in more complex ways:

{{functionA (functionB arg1 arg2) arg3}}

Which is roughly equivalent to functionA(functionB(arg1, arg2), arg3)

Using this as a starting place I developed a series of simple logical helper functions. Quickly the functions started looking more and more lisp like.

   {{#if (and predicate1 
              (or predicate2 predicate3) 
              (not predicate4)
              (eq val1 val3))}}
...some highly specific bit of content...
  {{/if}}

As an example, if you needed to output a list of things but wanted to add a special flag to the first item in the list, you could do it with my template helper package and Meteor 1.2 like so:

<ul>
   {{#each getThings}}
     <li class={{ifThenElse (eq @index 0) 'first-flag' null}}>
       {{thing.name}}
     </li>
   {{/each}}
</ul>

(the @index was a new addition in meteor 1.2, giving you access to the index value of an array)

While offloading too much logic into a template is perhaps not the best pattern, extending Spacebars with some simple logical helpers can reduce unneeded duplicate code when used responsibly.

This is especially true for Session values, that help define global client state. Rather than writing the below in every template needing to read a particular value from Session:

   
Template.MyTemplate.helpers({
        getSomeSessionVal() {
           return Session.get('currentUrl');
        }
   })

// then in markup

<p> current Url is : {{getSomeSessionVal}}  </p>

Instead, you could skip writing the helper in every template, and use a globally defined helper (included in the package) like this:

  
  <p> current Url is : {{Session 'currentUrl'}}  </p>

For a full list of the helpers and some examples please look at the docs (or the source).

The world always needs more LISP. enjoy.

title: An Open Letter to Adobe

author.name: Damian Taggart
author.description: Over the past decade Damian has grown Mindshare Studios from a very small (spare bedroom) operation into one of the more established and sought after web design and app development firms in the Southwest. Mindshare Studios won Small Business of the Year in 2014 from the Santa Fe Chamber of Commerce. Before founding Mindshare Studios, Damian worked as a web and multimedia developer for St. John’s College and Central New Mexico Community College, respectively. Damian has also worked doing freelance web design and internet/technology consulting. He is an avid open source technology enthusiast. Damian serves the City of Santa Fe on both the Economic Development Review Committee and the Business and Quality of Life Committee. Additionally, Damian is a co-owner of the experimental arts collective Meow Wolf which has partnered with George RR Martin to open a 20,000 square foot art experience in Santa Fe. Damian graduated cum laude with an interdisciplinary degree in Media Arts and English from the University of New Mexico in 2003. Damian lives in Santa Fe with his wife Lara and two sons, Jack and Henry.

content:
Dear Adobe,

I cancelled our Adobe Creative Cloud plan today. At Mindshare Studios we have been long term users, fans even, of Adobe and their products for about 20 years. I used to joke in the early 2000’s that I was only able to buy my first house thanks to Adobe Flash (I was primarily a freelance Flash developer at the time).

A History of Loyalty

I got my start with Adobe software in college in the late 90’s with Photoshop, ImageReady (yep, animating GIFs) and Dreamweaver (when DW was still a Macromedia product). Since that time I have continuously been a loyal customer of Adobe (and previously Macromedia). I also contributed to the Adobe community in numerous ways, including: writing free extensions for Dreamweaver and Flash (distributed widely on the Adobe Exchange), being a volunteer community leader in Albuquerque’s Adobe Users Group, authoring and publishing many tutorials on Adobe products, and I even did a short stint teaching Flash ActionScript 3 at UNM Continuing Education. I became an Adobe Certified Flash Developer and attended Adobe’s yearly conference, Adobe MAX, three times.

Adobe Corporate Culture

But times change, and technology changes even faster. Since the late 1990s a lot has happened in the world of web development and design and a lot has happened for Adobe. Almost 10 years ago, in 2005, Adobe Systems Inc bought their chief competitor, a smaller company called Macromedia. Macromedia was at the time the only real competitor for many of Adobe’s products including the flagship products Photoshop and Illustrator, just to name a few. This merger created a de facto monopoly for Adobe in the creative industry, with scant competition in any area except video editing (thanks to Final Cut Pro). Adobe hired a large team of talented lawyers to ensure the courts wouldn’t see this merger as the monopoly it is. Our justice system has always been particularly bad at handling issues relating to tech (mergers, patents, privacy, you name it).

In the 10 years since this monopoly began Adobe has dramatically reduced options for consumers while dramatically increasing its prices.

For the period ended May 30, Adobe reported a profit of $88.5 million, or 17 cents a share, up from $76.5 million, or 15 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding stock-based compensation and other items, adjusted per-share earnings rose to 37 cents from 36 cents. Revenue increased 5.7% to $1.07 billion.

Jun 17, 2014 [source]

Since 2005 Adobe has killed off a number of Macromedia’s products either quickly and directly (Freehand), by way of slow death due to lack of updates (Fireworks, Fontographer) or mismanagement (Flash). These are just a few examples off the top of my head but I’m certain there are more.

Aside from the reduction of meaning competition and choice for consumers, prices have gone way up. Gone are the days where you could choose to skip a version and only upgrade your Creative Suite every 3 years, Because of the de facto monopoly that Adobe now enjoys, they have been able to switch from a standard licensing model to a controversially priced monthly subscription plan. I have nothing against subscriptions for software by the way but in Adobe’s case, as a long time customer, the Creative Cloud really feels like price gouging.

A few years ago I participated in some lengthy Adobe surveys regarding the Creative Cloud pricing structure. These surveys outlined a wide range of alternative pricing that Adobe was considering, including a much more appealing option for metered usage (pay for how long you actually use the software.) A metered plan would make a lot of sense for my company, we probably have Adobe software running for maybe 1-3 hours per month at this point – more on this in a minute. None of these alternative pricing options materialized.

A Shift Toward Open Source

Over the past 10 years we largely outgrew most of the Adobe products that related to code (Dreamweaver, Flash, Flex Builder) and have moved to other products. This occurred primarily because Adobe kept their corporate focus on the widest possible market and didn’t keep pace with the more high end web development community (that needed more robust code editing and debugging tools.) Proprietary software has a number of fatal flaws, but the worst of which perhaps that a company that owns closed source software can kill off a product at any time, leaving the community of users with no recourse whatsoever.

The main sticking point keeping us on Adobe software has been on the design side of our work. Illustrator, InDesign, and Photoshop are all required tools for sharing files with virtually all graphic designers the world over. So we’ve kept our Creative Cloud subscription going on one Mac in our office expressly for this purpose. But today, I just decided it wasn’t worth it anymore, that I had had enough of paying the monthly fees (which have started to feel like extortion).

So I took a minute to reflect on all of the issues with Adobe Systems: the mismanagement, the focus on profits over customers or product development, the virtual monopoly on the creative industry, the lack of vision and leadership. Coupled with a growing distrust of closed source, proprietary software, I decided it was time move on and find another way of doing business.

Adobe Support: Let me quickly cancel your subscription. While I hate you see you go, it would be great to know if you think there was something that I could have offered which would have changed your decision?
Me: A more reasonable pricing policy. We barely use Adobe products in my company, but occasionally they are very helpful. But since we only use them a couple of time a month the $50 charge is crazy.
Adobe Support: Thank you for the feedbacks. I will pass this on to the relevant team.
Adobe Support: I see that you were paying initially $29.99 per month. Would you be willing to continue the subscription if I get you the same price again?
Me: No thank you. Just terminate it. We are going move on and find other software to use instead. I am also going to publish and promote a blog article about how much I dislike the pricing model Adobe uses, and the cancellation fee.
Adobe Support: Okay Damian, I have canceled the subscription and waived off the early termination fee as a goodwill gesture since you have been with us for a long time.
Me: Thank you. I will include that in my blog post.

Until today when I contacted Adobe support I wasn’t even aware there was going to be a cancellation fee (which would have been an astounding $175 in my case), Because I’m a good complainer they waived that. One point for complaining; niceness zero.

The Future

I don’t rule out that Adobe could turn this trend around. They might be able to recover some of the spirit that both Adobe and Macromedia possessed in their early years. That’s the main reason for this “open letter”. If you are out there listening, Adobe, in the immortal words of Ice Cube, you better “check yo’self before you wreck yo’self”.

Alternatives to Adobe Creative Cloud

To wrap up I’ll leave you with some of the tools we have found to be suitable replacements for many Adobe offerings. Here are a few of the alternative products we have replaced Adobe software with in our own workflow. These are either free and open source or commercial and reasonably priced.

Please post your additional suggestions in the comments!

Adobe Software Alternative
Dreamweaver Intellij IDEA (combines the features of PHPStorm / WebStorm)
Flash TweenJS
InDesign Scribus
Photoshop GIMP
Illustrator InkScape
